repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Health Sector Reconstruction
            and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Sector
            Recostruction and Development Project for Sierra Leone were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: more thought
            needs to be given to the general idea of 'exit'
            strategies. The opportunity for 'exit' starts at
            the design phase and continues by managing effective
            transition strategies and assisting the Government to
            transform such transitional arrangements into longer-term
            capacity development and performance. Grant financing was
            justified by the urgent need to restore a functioning health
            sector, its strong development impact and as a means to draw
            greater and broader support for the sector from other
            development partners. It should be recognized that until
            economic development takes off, the funding of the health
            sector will continue to largely depend upon donor funding.
            The present credit's sustainability cannot be ensured
            solely by the government until there is substantial
            macroeconomic development. Aspects of the project requiring
            continuous funding (civil works/maintenance, training
            medical personnel, and drug supplies) raise issues of
            sustainability over the long run, in case of diminishing
            support from donors. A shortage of health workers is a
            perennial problem in most African countries, especially in
            rural areas, and no satisfactory solutions have been found.
            The exodus of skilled health workers during the civil war
            exacerbated the problem in Sierra Leone. The country was
            also not immune from the recruiting practices of developed countries.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Health Sector Reconstruction
            and Development Project : project paper

abstracts.cdata!:
This paper is for an additional grant to
            Republic of Sierra Leone for the Health Sector
            Reconstruction and Development Project and to introduce
            changes in the project and accompanying amendments to the
            project's legal documents. This additional grant would
            help finance the costs associated with completing original
            civil works activities that face cost overruns, and
            implementing additional activities related to the control
            and prevention of onchocerciasis and avian influenza. This
            restructuring also supports modification of key performance
            indicators to strengthen the project focus on critical
            health outcomes, and scaling back of the malaria program in
            response to increased funding for these activities now
            available from other development partners. No changes to the
            project development objective, general design, and
            implementation modalities are sought. The proposed
            additional financing and the related project restructuring
            are designed to scale up the project's impact and
            development effectiveness, and help Sierra Leone speed up
            progress in restoring essential functions of the health
            delivery system.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Health Sector Recostruction
            and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Reconstruction and
            Development Project for Sierra Leone's objective is to
            help restore the most essential functions of the health
            delivery system. The project will achieve more specific
            objectives through two components. The first component will
            assist in restoring access to essential health services by:
            a) improving primary and first referral health facilities in
            four districts of the country; b) contributing to reducing
            the burden of some of the most important infectious diseases
            country-wide, by supporting Malaria and Tuberculosis control
            activities and the Sanitation program; c) strengthening
            health sector management capacity to improve efficiency and
            further decentralize decision making to the districts. The
            second component supports strengthening public and private
            sector capacity by: a) improving the quality of services; b)
            promoting development and regulation of the NGO sector,
            strengthening the quality of care and enhancing the
            contribution of the private sector; c) providing incentives
            to the health providers to establish practices in rural
            areas and smaller cities; d) contracting out clinical and
            non-clinical services with the private sector; and e)
            involving the civil society in decision making in health
            administration and in health facilities. This project will
            contribute to improve social conditions and alleviate
            poverty conditions that persist after a prolong civil war.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - HIV/AIDS Response Project
            and Health Sector Reconstruction and Development Project
            (HSRDP) : environmental assessments

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for both
            the HIV/AIDS Response Project (SHARP) and the Health Sector
            Reconstruction and Development Project (HSRDP) describes the
            comprehensive waste management plan made to counter
            anticipated negative environmental impacts. Appropriate
            design, sites and operation of sanitary landfills, leachate
            treatment and control, and water quality testing will reduce
            the risk of drinking water contamination. High temperature
            incineration, installation of flue gas cleaning devices, air
            quality testing, and non-incineration of materials
            containing chlorine or heavy metals will prevent release of
            pollutants into the air. Provision and ensuring the routine
            use of protective clothing, staff training, and teaching
            first aid will reduce the occurrence of occupational
            hazards. Limiting access to disposal sites, fencing of
            disposal sites, separating cells for medical wastes, and
            sensitizing the public through the media, particularly
            radio, television, posters, leaflets, newspapers, etc., will
            minimize disease transmission. Furthermore, all health care
            facilities will be equipped with appropriate equipment,
            materials, and facilities for collecting, managing, and
            transporting medical waste. Incinerators will be built and
            adapted for use in health facilities. Infectious hospital
            waste will be disposed of in sanitary landfills with set precautions.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Sierra Leone - Health Sector
            Reconstruction and Development Project : resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The taking of land and related assets
            may take place only after compensation has been paid and
            where applicable, resettlement sites, new homes, related
            infrastructure, public services, and moving allowances have
            been provided to displaced persons. Furthermore where
            relocation or loss of shelter occurs, measures to assist
            displaced persons are implemented in accordance with the
            resettlement plan of action. Also, land acquisition should
            be done in a way that satisfies public health requirements.
            Likely displaced persons will include 1) individuals who
            suffer loss of assets or investments, land or property,
            and/or access to natural and/or economic resources; 2)
            households who include members affected by such losses--that
            includes dependent relatives, friends, or tenants; 3)
            vulnerable individuals too old or ill to farm; 4) members of
            households who may not eat together but provide housekeeping
            or reproductive services critical to maintaining the family;
            and 4) other vulnerable persons. Because of the atrocities
            committed during the war, vulnerable households and persons
            such as internally displaced people like orphans, amputees,
            the elderly, and female heads of households may have
            different needs from most households or persons or needs
            unrelated to the amount of land available to them.
            Compensation would take the form of ensuring they are not
            separated from dependents or persons/s upon whom they depend
            for support; and rehabilitation and training to acquire
            vocational skills.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Health Sector Restructuring
            and Development Project (HSRDP) : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment
            establishes the Sierra Leone Health sector reconstruction
            and Development Project as a Category B project since its
            potential negative impacts are site-specific and easily
            manageable. The issues addressed mainly focus on the
            project's impact on the biophysical and socio-cultural
            environments of the Koinadugu, Kono, Moyomba, and Bombali
            districts. Possible impacts could include deforestation and
            land cover changes caused by landfill site development and
            building rehabilitation and construction, and the resulting
            loss of biodiversity and soil fertility through erosion; the
            danger open pits create to lives as causers of injury,
            receptacles for rubbish, and breeding grounds for
            mosquitoes; poor disposal of soil and paint materials
            leading to pollution; dust associated with earth preparation
            for rehabilitation works affecting air quality; loss of
            agricultural land and crop production; ineffective waste
            disposal impairing water quality, causing water
            contamination, and water-borne diseases. However, this
            report concludes that overall there are no significant
            environmental issues to be addressed apart from those
            referenced in the medical waste management plan under the
            HIV/AIDS Response Project (SHARP). The comprehensive waste
            management plan contains the following anticipated negative
            environmental impacts and their mitigations. Appropriate
            design, sites and operation of sanitary landfills, leachate
            treatment and control, and water quality testing will reduce
            the risk of drinking water contamination. High temperature
            incineration, installation of flue gas cleaning devices, air
            quality testing, and non-incineration of materials
            containing chlorine or heavy metals will prevent release of
            pollutants into the air. Provision and ensuring the routine
            use of protective clothing, staff training, and teaching
            first aid will reduce the occurrence of occupational
            hazards. Limiting access to disposal sites, fencing of
            disposal sites, separating cells for medical wastes, and
            sensitizing the public through the media, particularly
            radio, television, posters, leaflets, newspapers, etc., will
            minimize disease transmission. Furthermore, all health care
            facilities will be equipped with appropriate equipment,
            materials, and facilities for collecting, managing, and
            transporting medical waste. Incinerators will be built and
            adapted for use in health facilities. Infectious hospital
            waste will be disposed of in sanitary landfills with set precautions.
